title: Coalition MPs want wealthy private companies' tax payments kept private
text:
Wealthy families should not have to reveal their taxable income and the tax they pay, a Senate committee has found. by Joanna Mather Coalition MPs say private Australian companies with turnover of $100 million should not be required to disclose how much tax they pay – a rule designed to highlight which companies do and don't pay tax – because it could hurt their businesses.
A Senate committee looking at a proposal to exempt private companies from the new law said it was worried that revealing details about tax paid would "offend" long-held privacy protections. It also said the disclosure of market-sensitive information could place a company at a competitive disadvantage.
Labor and Greens MPs on the committee described the arguments used by Coalition MPs to justify the carve-out as "absurd, illogical, and often lacking any evidence".
"The ATO gave evidence during this inquiry that one in five private companies earning over $100 million do not pay any tax," they said in a dissenting report.
The committee has been examining legislation that would exempt about 800 privately held Australian companies from having their income tax payments included in a public report expected in 2015.
"This government should be making scrutiny of large Australian private companies a higher priority," the dissenting report by Labor and Greens MPs said.
The family that owns beef exporter Teys Australia told the committee it was worried it would be targeted by criminals on the basis of "perceived wealth" if details of its tax affairs were made public.
This followed concerns raised by Coalition MPs that revealing private wealth could make some Australians more vulnerable to kidnap attempts. But the majority report did not mention personal safety.
